body: would like the input of @fperez on tagged comment.
Continuation of https://github.com/ipython/nbconvert/pull/183
May want to wait to rebase until #3784 is merged.  :clock10:

ok, #3784 was merged, so pinging the status of this one.

Just glancing over this - there are no tests for this functionality at the moment, @jakobgager, could you add some?

I still feel the tagged comment are a weird thing and would like input of @fperez on that. I don't want to start Markenstein now.

Envoyé de mon iPhone

Le 4 août 2013 à 22:49, Paul Ivanov notifications@github.com a écrit :

> ok, #3784 was merged, so pinging the status of this one.
> 
> Just glancing over this - there are no tests for this functionality at the moment, @jakobgager, could you add some?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

Depending on the decision on tagged comments I"ll rebase after 1.0 has finally landed. 
Afterwards I'll try to add some tests (currently I have no real clue how to do, but will discover :smile: )

IMO there is no need to add this PR to 1.0 so I added the [ not for 1.0] tag to the description.
@jakobgager would you mind rebasing this?  I'd love to see this in master. :+1:   I'm tired of having to fix notebooks with embedded HTML by hand.
Add explicit mention to this issue in hackpad for april 15 so that @feprez to take a look. I suppose @fperez is really busy and do not look at github mentions, or github emails in general.

Rebased! ( :sweat_smile: this was my first rebase and it took me really long to figure out that I have to force the push)

@Carreau I understand your concern regarding markenstein, however, tagged comments do not change the markdown syntax at all and all available markdown parser will handle them as html comments.

@Carreau does the `no syntax change` in the hackpad from the last dev meeting mean remove the tagged comment stuff :smile:? 
I guess removing is better than just commenting as we have the tagged comments in the history anyway?

> no syntax change in the hackpad from the last dev meeting mean remove the tagged comment stuff :smile:? 

Yes, it was decided it was too much of a specific syntax to be added. We don't want to add "just one small thing" or otherwise they will pile-up. We will come to a mechanism to deal with citation or things like that, but we need something more generic than thoses tags comment. Brian has some ideas about that, which should also bind nicely with the literate computing and beeing able to reference variable values in markdown cell.

OK, will remove those! 
Reference variables in markdown cells will be awesome!
With tagged comments removed, what is the benefit of the changes here?

see #3503 - tagged comments were just a small addition but not the main purpose of this PR.

I'm currently adding some tests.

But pandoc still strips the comment when converting from html to latex:

``` python
In [6]: s = "foo <!-- comment --> bar"

In [7]: markdown2latex(s)
Out[7]: u'foo bar'

In [8]: extended_markdown2latex(s)
Out[8]: u'foo barfoo bar'
```

So this change doesn't actually achieve the goal of preserving comments, and it also doesn't seem to properly parse the markdown.

The goal is **not** to preserve comments (my mistake in #3503 - Updated) but to preserve html tags! So it does ``` python In [2]: s = 'foo bar bar2' In [3]: extended_markdown2latex(s) Out[3]: u'foo \\emph{bar} bar2' ``` Of course emphasis can be get using pure markdown, but this way you can e.g. create tables. Thanks, for the bug report (was a problem with intiation).
@jdfreder can you try some of your notebooks?

@jakobgager what in your goal cannot be achieved by simply using HTML as an intermediary, rather than trying to parse it out and treat the two separately:

``` python
html2latex(markdown2html(s))
```

I guess you mean **can** be achieved - and you are totally right! Once the tagged comments are removed there is no need to parse the html! Great that others have an unbiased view on this :sweat_smile:

So it is better to close this PR and make a new one with just the combination.

@minrk your proposed approach (as simple and beautiful it is) unfortunately does not handle math environments correctly:

``` python
s = 'foo $\\alpha$ bar'

In [4]: html2latex(markdown2html(s))
Out[4]: u'foo \\textbackslash{}(\\textbackslash{}alpha\\textbackslash{}) bar'

In [5]: extended_markdown2latex(s)
Out[5]: u'foo $\\alpha$ bar'
```

Major drawback of the current implementation: markdown embedded in html tags is not converted. 
-> I'm not perfectly happy with this :unamused:

Can you provide a notebook with a variety of examples that this filter handles better than the existing naïve one?  The main issue is that we are trying very hard to confine the scope of nbconvert to be truly minimal, and let more customized functionality be delivered by adding things like custom filters and templates via config.  So I'm trying to understand whether this enhancement is within scope.

That's why I asked @jdfreder which kind of notebooks he has to fix manually. The naive approach cannot handle math so I would suggest not to use it now. 
My current implementation is not ready to be merged, regardless of within scope or not (there are too many issues as described above). 
First, I would like to find out which types of html tags to expect and if there is a better way to handle them.
Sorry, by naïve I meant using markdown2latex, not markdown2html2latex, which has clear problems.
Do you have a minute on hipchat?

Summary of chat with @minrk:
1. Wait for input of @jdfreder, to have an idea on which kind of html tags are to be handled 
2. Get pandoc to handle math in html inputs correctly to enable a markdown2html2latex conversion
3. Better communicate the "new" [marked](/chjj/marked)  markdown syntax (docs and example notebooks) - includes tables!

Optional workaround (not to prefered):
- Similar it is currently done with js, extract_math | md2html | html2latex | insert_math

Note: Many html attributes will not be handled correctly (whatever approach we will finally use) including width, height as these are not captured by pandoc.
Will close here and continue discussion in #3503.
Sorry @jakobgager , this fell off my radar somehow.  _Off the top of my head_ I was having trouble with **img** and **table** html tags not being parsed.
